sen.j: 落語家（らくごか）は、落語を演じて視聴させることを職業とする人。
sen.e: A rakugoka performs rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) to have it watched as an occupation.
A rakugoka performs rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) as an occupation.
A rakugoka performs rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) as an occupation.

sen.j: 戦前は、寄席がおもな活動の拠点で、グループを組んで地方公演も行っていた。
sen.e: Before the war, they mainly performed at the yose (storyteller theater) and, made a group to perform also on the road.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Before the war, they mainly performed at the yose (storyteller theater) and, also made a group to perform on the road.

sen.j: が、戦後はその話術を生かしテレビ番組やラジオ番組の司会、ラジオパーソナリティなどの副業をすることも多い。
sen.e: After the war, however, they often act as a host of TV or radio programs as well as a radio personality as a sideline, taking advantage of their verbal skills.

sen.j: 「話家」「噺家」「咄家」（はなしか）は、「落語家」の古い表現である。
sen.e: Hanashika (a story teller)' is an old expression for a rakugoka.
Hanashika (a story teller)' is an old expression for a rakugoka.
Hanashika' (a story teller) is an old expression for a rakugoka.

sen.j: 落語家の演ずる噺は大別して二種類ある。
sen.e: There are roughly two types of stories that a rakugoka performs.
There are roughly two types of stories that a rakugoka performs.
There are roughly two types of stories that a rakugoka performs.

sen.j: 落とし噺：噺の終わりに「落ち（「さげ」とも言う）」が有る噺。
sen.e: Stories with a punch line: A story with 'ochi (also called 'sage'),' a punch line, in the end.
Stories with a punch line: A story with 'ochi (also called 'sage'),' a punch line, at the end.
Stories with a punch line: A story with 'ochi' (also called 'sage'), a punch line, at the end.

sen.j: 「落語」はこれに該当する。
sen.e: Rakugo' falls under this.
Rakugo' falls under this.
Rakugo' falls under this.

sen.j: 人情噺：噺の終わりに「落ち」が無い噺。
sen.e: Stories with a moving end: A story without 'ochi' in the end.
Stories with a moving end: A story without 'ochi' at the end.
Stories with a moving end: A story without 'ochi' at the end.

sen.j: 基本的に続き続き・・・で引っぱっていく。
sen.e: It basically leads with going on and on.
It basically goes on and on.
It basically goes on and on.

sen.j: 怪談噺等もこれに属する。
sen.e: Ghost story telling also belongs to this.
Ghost story telling also belongs to this.

sen.j: このため、「落語家」という表現は、厳密には 1. のみを語る者ということになり、1. 2. 両方語る場合「噺家」の方が適切な呼称である。
sen.e: Therefore, the expression 'rakugoka' technically tells only 1, and 'hanashika' is a more appropriate name in case of telling both 1 and 2.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the expression 'rakugoka' technically fits only description 1, and 'hanashika' is a more appropriate name describing both 1 and 2.

sen.j: が、1.に属する一部の噺も人情噺として捉える主張の存在もあり、現在は「落語家」で定着している。
sen.e: However, some insist that some stories belonging to 1 are considered to be a stories with a moving end, so 'rakugoka' is fixed currently.

sen.j: 江戸時代には狂歌や雑俳に関わる人々など素人の咄家も活躍していた。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, amateur story tellers including those who were involved in kyoka (comic and satirical tanka) and playful literature originating from haiku were in active.

sen.e: During the Edo Period, amateur story tellers including those who were involved in kyoka (comic and satirical tanka) and playful literature originating from haiku were inactive.

sen.j: が、やがて烏亭焉馬や三笑亭可楽などの職業咄家たちがあらわれた。
sen.e: Then later, professional story tellers such as Enba UTEI and Karaku SANSHOTEI appeared.

sen.j: その身分は（見習い、）前座、二つ目、真打からなる。
sen.e: Its ranks consist of (minarai (apprentice)), zenza (opening act), futatsume (a status between an amateur and professional), shinuchi (full-fledged master of story-telling).
Its ranks consist of (minarai or apprentice), zenza (opening act), futatsume (status between amateur and professional), shinuchi (full-fledged master of story-telling).

sen.j: この区分けがあるのは、現在では東京だけであり、上方と名古屋ではこれらの身分は存在しない。
sen.e: This classification currently exists only in Tokyo, and these ranks don't exist in Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area) and Nagoya.

sen.j: 見習い（みならい）

sen.j: 弟子入りを志願した師匠から入門の許可を得た落語家の卵。
sen.e: An aspiring rakugoka who was permitted to initiate by the master to be taken on as his disciple.

sen.j: 入門したあと、前座名（名前）を師匠から貰い、前座登録をして、前座として楽屋入りするまでは「見習い」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: After the initiation, they get a zenza name, register as a zenza, and are called 'minarai' until they enter the backstage as a zenza.

sen.j: 正規の身分制度にはもともと存在しないが、前座の数が多いのでそれまでの待機をする。
sen.e: Although this does not originally exist as an official ranking system, there are too many zenza, so they stand by for it.
Although this did not originally exist as an official ranking system, there are too many zenza, so they are put on stand by to receive it.

sen.j: おもに師匠宅で師匠・その家族のために家事などの下働き・雑用をする。
sen.e: They mainly do their leg work and chores such as housework for his master and his family at the master's residence.

sen.j: 休みはない。

sen.j: 昔は師匠宅に住み込みで身の回りの世話をすることもあったが、現在は通いの方が多い。
sen.e: Though some lived in the master's residence and took care of him before, more people lived out now.

sen.j: 食事は師匠宅でするので（作るのは見習い本人だが）食費は要らない。

sen.j: 娯楽等を楽しむことは禁じられている。

sen.j: 見習いと前座は、（落語家社会では、）人間ではない。

sen.j: 前述の師匠宅の仏教における前座（まえざ）説教が語源。
sen.e: The origin of the name is Buddhist teaching called maeza (前座) at the master's residence mentioned above.

sen.j: 前述の、師匠宅の家事・雑用の他に、寄席での仕事（前座修行）が課せられる。
sen.e: They are imposed works at the yose, a storyteller theater (zenza training) as well as the housework and chores at the master's residence mentioned above.
They are expected to work at the yose, the storyteller theater (zenza training) as well as doing the housework and chores at the master's residence mentioned above.

sen.j: 寄席での、呼び込み太鼓・鳴り物・めくりの出し入れ・色物の道具の用意と回収・マイクのセッティング・茶汲み・着物の管理など楽屋、寄席共に毎日雑用をこなす。
sen.e: They perform odd jobs both at the backstage and the yose everyday, such as the drum signalling beginning of a performance, musical instruments, carrying in and out mekuri (title board), preparation and collection of tools for iromono (various entertainments in storytellers' theater other than story telling), setting a microphone, serving tea and managing kimono.

sen.e: Enkyo TACHIBANAYA (the fourth), who was known as the best master, was once promoted to futatsume, but he climbed down to zenza voluntarily to earn money to support his parents (Kazuo SEKIYAMA "Rakugo Meijinden" (Rakugo Masters)).
